sections.heading: Core Function
sections.content:
の connects two nouns to show relationship, possession, or attribution.

Think of it as "'s" or "of" in English.

children.heading: 1. Possession
children.content: 私の本 - "my book" 田中さんの車 - "Tanaka's car" 日本の文化 - "Japan's culture"

children.heading: 2. Description/Attribute
children.content: 木の机 - "wooden desk" (desk of wood) 赤の車 - "red car" 日本語の先生 - "Japanese teacher"

children.heading: 3. Location/Origin
children.content: 東京の会社 - "Tokyo company" (company in Tokyo) 図書館の本 - "library book"

children.heading: 4. Apposition
children.content:
Clarifying/explaining:

学生の田中さん - "Tanaka, the student" 友達の山田 - "Yamada, my friend"

children.heading: 5. Nominalization
children.content:
Turn verbs/sentences into nouns:

泳ぐの - "swimming" 食べるのが好き - "like eating"

sections.heading: の Chains
sections.content:
Multiple の can be chained:

私の友達の本 "my friend's book" 日本語の勉強の本 "Japanese study book" 東京の大学の学生 "Tokyo university student"

sections.heading: の vs な
sections.content:
Don't confuse with な-adjectives:

静かな部屋 - "quiet room" (な-adjective) 私の部屋 - "my room" (possession)

children.heading: こと vs の
children.content:
Both nominalize verbs:

泳ぐことが好き - "like swimming" (abstract) 泳ぐのが好き - "like swimming" (colloquial)

の is more casual/spoken.

children.heading: Before が/を
children.content:
の acts as noun:

勉強するのが難しい "Studying is difficult" 本を読むのが好き "Like reading books"

sections.heading: Possessive Hierarchy
sections.content:
Order matters:

私の友達の本 my friend's book 友達の私の本 ✗ (confusing)

sections.heading: Replacing Nouns
sections.content:
の can replace previously mentioned nouns:

A: どの車ですか？ "Which car?" B: 赤いのです "The red one" 私のはこれです "Mine is this"

children.heading: With verbs directly (need nominalization)
children.content: ✗ 食べるの本 ✓ 食べ物 "food" (compound noun)

children.heading: Between adjectives and nouns
children.content: ✗ 大きいの犬 ✓ 大きい犬 "big dog"

sections.heading: の in Questions
sections.content: 誰のですか？ - "Whose is it?" どこのですか？ - "Where is it from?" 何のですか？ - "What kind?"

children.heading: である
children.content:
In formal writing:

日本の文化 → 日本である文化

children.heading: に関する
children.content:
"Regarding":

日本の本 → 日本に関する本 "book about Japan"

sections.heading: Key Takeaways
sections.content:
✓ Connects nouns (possession/description) ✓ Can chain multiple の ✓ Replaces mentioned nouns ✓ Nominalizes verbs (casual) ✓ Think: "'s" or "of"

Related:

Nominalization の vs こと Noun Basics
